column2: The Command-line - Cat and Mouse
What you'll do
Start learning about the command-line, the most powerful tool on any computer. (Part 1 of 4)
Hey {{user_name}}! Ada's always saying we should search out new things to do - so I want to try teaching you some tricks in the Terminal!
The Terminal is mondo cool, it's where the REAL magic in the OS happens. You know those scenes in movies where they hack into computer systems?
That's supposed to look like the Terminal. I'm going to teach you the real stuff, though!
Just a couple things before we start - when I do text like this, it's important.
Text like this is a command - something you could type into the terminal. Pay close attention to spelling, captialization, and spacing, the Terminal is very picky.
Also, pay attention to the results of what you type - If there's an error, you probably mistyped something.
Let's get started - I'll open the Terminal open for you.
Nice. See that text on the left there? That's called the prompt. It tells you a lot of info, but the important part is that the part after the colon (:) tells you where you are in the filesystem.
Right now, that should show ~ (tilde), which means we're in your home directory, where all your files are.
BTW, a file system is like a big group of folders, and some of them contain more folders inside them, and so on.
To see what's around you in the current folder, you use the command ls
ls is a command that lists everything in the directory you're in. It's like looking around in a room.
Type ls (lower-case L, lower-case S) into the Terminal, then hit Enter.
Running ls should have shown you a list of items, then given you a new prompt.
Whenever you see a new, empty prompt, the Terminal is ready for another command. It's super fast!
If you had already saved any files in your home directory, you might see them in the results of that ls.
Hmm, did you create a directory named yarnbasket? That sounds like something a cat would do. Let's check it out!
To go into another folder, you use the cd command.
cd stands for change directory (directory is another word for folder). Unlike ls, cd needs some information after it to tell it which directory you want to change to.
Since we want to go into yarnbasket, type cd yarnbasket, then hit enter
Your prompt should now say yarnbasket, since you typed in cd yarnbasket.
Now that you're inside this folder, type ls again to see what's inside.
Huh. That's a lot of yarn. Well, I guess we're going to have to investigate it!
Let's enter the directory redyarn - remember how we just got in here?
cd redyarn will get us where we want to go. Now, let's ls to look around.
Nothing here. Oh well. To get back out, we need to use a special version of cd, written as cd ..
That's cd (space) period period - It means "go up one level", which will take us back to yarnbasket, in this case.
OK, here we are again. If you entered cd .. here, where do you think we'd go? Try it, and don't forget to ls after.
Hey, look, we should be back in your home directory. Use ls to check, if you didn't already.
Let's get back to yarnbasket, so type cd yarnbasket.
And now ls again, so we can see all the other folders we need to check.
Let's try greenyarn.
That's cd greenyarn, then ls.
Nothing again! Why is this called "yarnbasket" if there's no yarn? Let's go back.
cd .. takes us back, and now ls to check what's here.
One folder left to check. Take us into blueyarn!
And let's see what we've got! (ls)
Aha! A mouse! No wonder there was no yarn, this mouse ate it all!
Fortunately, I have a perfect solution. Felix! Come take care of this mouse!
Nyan, brrrp? Miao&^w!
<Felix licks his nose, and vanishes into an air duct.>
I love that cat, but he drives me nuts sometimes. He never does anything when you need him to!
Well, if Felix won't help us, we'll just have to use a different "cat".
The program cat helps you open files - it shows their data on the screen, right in the terminal.

You can use cat on any file - just type cat filename - but only text files will show you anything you can read. If you forget to type a filename after cat, you can use Ctrl-C to get back to the prompt.
OK, let's check out that file - type cat mouse to cat the file named mouse.
LOL! Looks like Felix is playing pranks on us.
It says the mouse got away, huh? To "greener pastures". Maybe that's a clue to the color of the yarn he's hiding in!
Let's get out of here and find that mouse! Remember, use cd .. to get out of a folder.
Now, back into greenyarn, and ls to see if that mouse is hiding there.
Ha! Let's cat that file and see if we got him!
Not again! This is a clever mouse, but he's running out of places to hide. Quick, back into yarnbasket and then into redyarn!
Ok, now that we're in redyarn, let's ls and see what's hiding in here.
Now we've got him! Let's cat that file!
Gotcha! But he is awfully cute, I suppose. We'll let him go today. After all, he isn't doing anything bad, really.
That was fun! You learned ls, cd, and cat - and I've got much more planned for next time!
Catch you later!
